Module xyz.jmburns.rangefun
Package xyz.jmburns.rangefun

Class Progression

  • java.lang.Object
    • xyz.jmburns.rangefun.Progression
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Comparable<Progression>, java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Integer>

    public final class Progression
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Integer>, java.lang.Comparable<Progression>
    This class represents an progression of integers, as built by the Progressions API. The class is also fully suitable for use in Map and Collection instances, since it provides well-behaved implementations of equals, hashCode, and compareTo. It is also designed to be completely immutable.

    • Method Detail

      • reverse

        public Progression reverse​()
        Creates a new Progression instance whose starting value is this progression's ending value, and whose ending value is this progression's starting value. For example, progression(1, 5, 1).reverse().equals(progression(5, 1, 1) will evaluate to true. This method is intended to be used to easily iterate backwards over an array.
        Returns:
        a new Progression instance, created from this one, but with values swapped so that the progression is iterated backwards.

      • contains

        public boolean contains​(int integer)
        Determines whether or not iteration over this progression would produce the given integer. For example, Progressions.progression(1, 5, 2).contains(3) would evaluate to true, while Progressions.range(7, 5).contains(4) would evaluate to false.
        Parameters:
        integer - the integer whose range is to be evaluated
        Returns:
        true if iteration over this progression would produce the given integer, false otherwise
        See Also:
        Progressions.progression(int, int, int), Progressions.range(int, int)
        Implementation Note:
        Progressions are lazily-evaluated, so this method is guaranteed to run in constant time.

      • get

        public int get​(int index)
        Returns the integer at the specified index in the progression. Indexing begins at zero. For example, Progressions.range(5, 9).get(2) would evaluate to 7, since 7 is the third (counting from zero) integer in the range of 5, 6, 7, 8, 9.
        Parameters:
        index - the index to look up
        Returns:
        the integer at the specified index in the progression
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the given index is negative or greater than or equal to length()
        See Also:
        toArray(), Progressions.range(int, int)
        Implementation Note:
        Progressions are lazily-evaluated, so repeated calls to get(int) may not provide optimal performance. In those cases, it might be worth calling toArray() and accessing the returned array by index instead, since it would produce the same results, without unnecessary recalculation.

      • toArray

        public java.lang.Integer[] toArray​()
        Returns a new Integer array filled with all the integers in this progression, in iteration order. For example, Progressions.range(1, 5).toArray() will evaluate to an array containing the integers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.
        Returns:
        a new Integer array filled by all the integers in this progression
        See Also:
        Progressions.range(int, int)

      • length

        public int length​()
        Calculates the length of this progression, with the step value taken into account. For example, progression(0, 6, 2).length() will evaluate to 3.
        Returns:
        the length of the progression

      • iterator

        public java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Integer> iterator​()
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Integer>
        Returns:
        a new Iterator over this progression
